;;欧洲央行;已暂停这是自欧元推出以来最艰难的一次加息周期，人们对欧元区经济的担忧日益加剧，判断之前的加息足以应对通胀。

;

;在金融市场普遍预期的一项决定中，欧洲央行一年多来首次维持其关键政策利率不变，从而停止了此前十轮借贷成本的上涨。

;

;在此之际，人们越来越担心先前的利率上涨对欧洲经济体的影响，并发出单一货币地区经济衰退的警告 ;受德国经济低迷的影响;，制造业低迷导致 10 月份商业活动连续第四个月萎缩。

;

;由于通胀率超过央行目标的两倍，经济学家预计借贷成本将在很长一段时间内保持在较高水平，以冷却整个 20 个国家集团的价格增长。

;

;最新决定将欧洲央行对商业银行存款支付的存款利率维持在 4%，这是自欧元于 1999 年推出。其主要再融资操作利率（向银行系统提供大量流动性）保持在 4.5% 不变，而边际贷款便利利率（向银行提供隔夜信贷）则保持在 4.75%。 /p>;

;
;

;;相关：;;选举否认者、气候怀疑论者、反堕胎：美国众议院新议长迈克·约翰逊的七大信念;

;
;

;

;

;尽管面临 91 项刑事指控和各种民事威胁，特朗普在明年共和党总统提名的民意调查中保持巨大领先。

;

;盖茨，一位专门的煽动者;面临;众议院针对不当性行为和滥用资金指控进行的道德调查，据报道其目标是竞选佛罗里达州州长。

; <周三，前共和党特工、现任反特朗普林肯项目顾问的杰夫·蒂默（Jeff Timmer）评估了盖茨的说法，即“马加正在崛起”，并;说;：“说起来很奇怪，但马特·盖茨的说法是正确的。”

;

;盖茨告诉班农·约翰逊“很敏锐”，并且会“在我们的家庭中受到尊重”最有意义、最正义、最爱国的捐助者，就像他在集会上与我们最热情、最有意义的活动家一样。

;

;“……他们在 K 街哭泣，他们绞手，他们尿床” – 华盛顿特区游说业的中心 – “因为我们有一位正直的、正直的人即将担任这个职位。他将为国家做出伟大的事情。”

;

;周二晚上，当约翰逊宣布他将成为议长时，一名记者问他在特朗普选举颠覆中扮演的角色。

; <即使在 1 月 6 日发生致命骚乱之后，路易斯安那州仍有 147 名共和党人投票反对关键州的结果。他还在一起旨在推翻结果的案件中向美国最高法院撰写了一份法庭之友陈述，吸引了 125 名支持者。

;

;在国会大厦，约翰逊微笑着摇了摇头，而周围的共和党人则;嘘声和嘲笑;。< /p>;

;“闭嘴，”来自北卡罗来纳州的 80 岁弗吉尼亚福克斯说。 “闭嘴。”

;

;约翰逊说：“下一个问题。”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 19:52:01 +0800 Sandro Tonali: Italian FA agrees 10-month ban for Newcastle footballerhttps://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/oct/26/sandro-tonali-newcastle-banned-10-month-over-betting

;;桑德罗·托纳利反思纽卡斯尔周三输给多特蒙德
;

;纽卡斯尔中场桑德罗·托纳利将意大利足球联合会（FIGC）主席表示，因违反意大利赌博法规而被禁止参加足球比赛 10 个月。加布里埃尔·格拉维纳 (Gabriele Gravina) 表示，作为协议的一部分，托纳利还将接受为期八个月的康复期。

;

;托纳利的经纪人表示，他的客户有赌博成瘾，托纳利全力配合意大利的调查。托纳利承认在比赛中下注，其中包括他为米兰效力的一些比赛。 7 月份，他以 5500 万英镑从米兰加盟纽卡斯尔。

;

;意大利的职业足球运动员不得投注国际足联、欧足联或意大利足协组织的任何比赛。这样做将受到三年禁令的处罚，不过认罪后可能会减少禁令。

; ;

;“FIGC检察官和托纳利已经达成一项协议，我已经批准了，”格拉维纳说。 “协议包括 10 个月的禁令，加上 8 个月的康复活动和至少 16 次公开露面。”

;

;托纳利的律师本周在意大利为这位 23 岁的人谈判认罪协议，他;承诺了他的俱乐部的全力支持;。纽卡斯尔主教练埃迪·豪上周五表示：“我们将拥抱桑德罗并保护他，并尽力给予他所需的爱和支持，以找到他所遇到的问题的解决方案。我们看到他多年来一直是我们团队的一员。我们对他有长期的承诺。”

;

;尤文图斯中场球员尼科洛·法吉奥利上周;因违反比赛投注规则而被禁赛七个月;，作为与意大利足联达成的和解协议的一部分。他被禁赛 12 个月，其中 5 个月被禁赛，并被罚款 12,500 欧元（10,843 英镑）。他还同意针对赌博问题的治疗计划。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 19:22:01 +0800 UK regulator trying to block release of Shell North Sea documentshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/26/uk-regulator-trying-block-release-shell-north-sea-documents
;;2023-10-26T10:16:05Z;
;
;;布伦特布拉沃石油平台运至蒂斯河河口，将于 2019 年 6 月退役
;< p>;英国石油和天然气监管机构因利用律师试图阻止与壳牌在北海活动对环境影响有关的五份关键文件的公开而受到环保组织的批评。

;

;在 12 月举行的听证会上，北海过渡管理局 (NSTA) 的一名法律代表预计将反对公布包含布伦特油田退役造成的污染风险详细信息的文件，该油田由壳牌运营超过40 年。它表示“基于程序问题”反对发布。

;

;壳牌已申请豁免遵守国际规则，该规则要求将所有基础设施从现场拆除，英国政府正在决定是否允许石油公司为 Bravo、Charlie 和 Delta 三个平台保留 170 米高的石油平台支腿。

;

;支腿结构中总共包含 64 个混凝土储存单元，其中 42 个为混凝土储存单元。以前用于石油储存和分离。

;

;大多数单元的大小相当于七个奥林匹克游泳池，合计 ;估计仍含有 72,000 吨受污染沉积物;和 638,000 立方米含油水。

;

;环境团体认为，NSTA 持有的文件将揭示与其他北海石油开发相关的长期环境危险的新信息，包括 ;Equinor 计划开发英国最大的未开发油田 Rosebank;。

;

;听证会涉及的五份文件包括现场退役计划和现场环境评估的更新版本，以及与放射性沉积物和有毒钻屑有关的技术文件。

;

;早期版本所有五份文件均作为 2016 年和 2017 年磋商过程的一部分发布，根据信息专员办公室 (ICO) 发布的声明，最新版本已更新，以反映已进行的进一步磋商。

;

;这些文件包括装置的退役建议、电池内所含物质的详细信息，以及与这些物质在短期和长期内的潜在环境影响相关的研究。

;

;Lang Banks世界自然基金会苏格兰分会主任表示：“监管机构将公共资金花在律师身上，试图阻止很久以前就应该公开的文件被公开，这绝对是一场闹剧。

;

;“如果他们准备使用这些文件作为规划和许可流程的一部分，那么他们也应该准备将其公开。”

;

;Tessa Khan，国际气候危机和人权律师兼运动团体 Uplift 的执行董事认为，监管机构不让这些文件进入公共领域的努力是为了石油和天然气行业的利益，但却以牺牲环境和公众为代价。

; < p>;“NSTA 的职责是充当独立监管机构，但只要它存在，它就一直偏向石油和天然气公司，包括与行业勾结如何最好地向公众销售新钻探产品，”;她告诉天空新闻;.

;

;“也许这并不奇怪，因为前石油和天然气高管担任 NSTA 董事会成员，并且其一些成员仍然持有该行业的股份。”

;

;调查性新闻组织 ;Point Source; 于 2022 年 7 月根据《信息自由法》提出请求，首次要求监管机构公布这些文件

;

;当年 9 月，NSTA 表示已咨询过壳牌公司，随后决定无权公布这些文件，因为这些文件是代表第三方持有的，而该第三方持有不同意公开这些文件。

;

;2023 年 5 月，ICO 发布了一项决定，称 NSTA 未能在法定时限内对请求做出适当回应是“不可接受的”，并且违反了《环境信息条例》。

;

;ICO 随后命令监管机构公布这些文件，或者在 35 天内给出不提供这些文件的有效法律理由。 NSTA 尚未公布这些文件，并将在 12 月的听证会上向法官辩论其案件。

;

;一些竞选团体表示，他们认为 NSTA 发起的最新法律上诉是一种旨在阻止环境信息在政府敏感时间浮出水面。

;

;此案将由总监管商会审理，该总监管商会负责处理针对政府监管机构决策的上诉。

;

;上个月，NSTA 的做法;已批准开发位于设得兰群岛附近的罗斯班克油气田;。

;

;政府还;最近推出了新的许可回合;允许石油和天然气公司在北海勘探化石燃料。

;

;伦敦自由化石运动组织主任罗宾·威尔斯 (Robin Wells) 表示：“至关重要的是，监管机构分享其掌握的有关现有油田环境影响的新信息，以便就是否开发更多油田做出明智的决定。”

;

;;此前公布的环境评估文件;称，壳牌废弃遗骸对环境的影响存在很大程度的不确定性北海布伦特平台的情况。

;

;他们指出，不确定性领域之一是处理细胞污染内容物的最佳方法，因为放射性水平“目前未知”。< /p>;

;文件称，仅从受污染的沉积物中采集了非常有限的样品。

;

;样品仅从 64 个单元中的 3 个单元的顶部 50 厘米沉积物中采集，并且只有 6 千克沉积物和 10 千克沉积物。从估计数千万公斤的沉积物和数亿升的含油水中测试了数升的水。

;

;此前公布的文件称，可能会释放出 261 公斤的汞，有毒物质菲可能会释放出来。随着污染物开始从腐烂的混凝土细胞中泄漏，对 1.7 平方公里范围内的海床产生化学影响。

;

;文件还称，随着细胞水释放的石油的很大一部分预计将到达海面，这可能会影响海鸟。

;

;2019年，公开的环境评估文件受到德国和其他欧盟成员国的严厉批评，他们表示壳牌对潜在环境损害的评估过于保守。他们;说剩下的石油和污染物是一颗“定时炸弹”;。

;

;;A德国政府委托编写的报告;表示，壳牌在其公开的环境影响评估中使用的方法存在“根本性缺陷”，并且包含“高度的数学偏差”。

;

;德国政府发言人NSTA 表示：“退役决定和环境评估的责任不属于 NSTA 的职权范围，而是由海上石油环境和退役监管机构 (OPRED) 负责。 NSTA 正在对 ICO 在流程问题上披露某些信息的决定提出上诉。”

;

;壳牌在一份声明中表示：“我们的建议是 10 年研究的结果，涉及300多项科学技术研究。我们成立了一个独立的科学专家小组来审查调查结果，并确保对所有可行的退役方案进行彻底调查。”

;

;该石油公司补充道：“壳牌提交文件是严格控制流程的一部分。监管机构充分了解它们将在适当的时候发布。其方式和时间安排由监管机构决定。”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 18:22:02 +0800 Pigeons problem-solve similarly to artificial intelligence, research showshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/26/pigeons-smart-ai-learning
;;2023-10-26T09:00:30Z;
;
;;一只鸽子对着镜头怒目而视
;

;一个新的 ;研究;发现鸽子解决问题的方式与人工智能相匹配。

;

;经常被忽视令人讨厌的是，鸽子实际上是非常聪明的动物，它们可以记住面孔，以鲜艳的色彩看到世界，导航复杂的路线，传递新闻，甚至;拯救生命;。

;
;

;;相关：;;研究发现，公鸡可能能够识别自己的倒影;

;
;

;在这项研究中，24 只鸽子被赋予了各种视觉任务，其中一些它们在几天内学会了分类，而另一些则在几周内学会了分类。研究人员发现证据表明，鸽子用来做出正确选择的机制与人工智能模型用来做出正确预测的方法非常相似。

;

;“鸽子的行为表明，大自然已经创造了一种高度精确的算法。该研究的合著者、爱荷华大学实验心理学教授爱德华·沃瑟曼（Edward Wasserman）说：“它可以有效地学习非常具有挑战性的任务。” “不一定要以最快的速度，但要保持高度的一致性。”

;

;在屏幕上，鸽子会受到不同的刺激，例如不同宽度、位置和方向的线条，以及分段环和同心环。每只鸟必须啄一下右侧或左侧的按钮来决定它们属于哪一类。如果他们猜对了，他们就会得到颗粒状的食物；如果猜对了，他们就会得到颗粒状的食物。如果他们做错了，他们就一无所获。

;

;“鸽子不需要规则，”该研究的主要作者、俄亥俄州立大学心理学教授布兰登·特纳说。相反，他们通过反复试验来学习。例如，当他们看到一个视觉效果时，比如“A 类”，任何看起来接近的东西都会被他们归类为“A 类”，从而发挥他们识别相似性的能力。

;

;通过实验，鸽子在处理一些较简单的任务时做出正确选择的能力从 55% 提高到 95%。面对更复杂的挑战，它们的准确率从 55% 提高到 68%。

;

;“使用鸽子等更卑微的动物，我们可以测试它们能够走多远，[我们认为]波鸿鲁尔大学行为神经科学教授 Onur Güntürkün 没有参与这项研究，他说：“完全或大部分是联想。” “这篇论文展示了联想系统有多么强大，它们是多么真实的认知。”

;

;在人工智能模型中，主要目标是识别模式并做出决策。研究表明，鸽子也能做到这一点。从后果中学习，当没有给予食物颗粒时，鸽子具有非凡的纠正错误的能力。相似性函数也对鸽子起作用，通过利用它们寻找两个物体之间相似性的能力。

;

;“仅凭这两种机制，您就可以定义一个神经网络或人工智能机器来基本上解决这些问题分类问题，”特纳说。 “按理说，人工智能中存在的机制也存在于鸽子中。”

;

;;雷切尔·里维斯手里拿着纸杯坐着
;

;影子财政大臣雷切尔·里维斯，她关于女性经济学家的新书被指控明显抄袭。

;

;英国《金融时报》对该书的审查，;创造现代经济学的女性;，找到了 20 多个段落的例子其他来源似乎要么被批量删除，要么经过细微修改而未经确认。

;

;该论文引用的例子包括《卫报》的讣告、几个维基百科条目以及工党前座议员的一段话.

;

;该书的出版商 Basic Books 承认书中的句子没有正确引用。里夫斯办公室否认抄袭，但承认存在错误，并表示将予以纠正。

;

;发言人 ;告诉英国《金融时报》;：“我们强烈反驳本报向我们提出的指控。 These were inadvertent mistakes and will be rectified in future reprints.”

;

;Basic Books pointed out that the book includes a bibliography from more than 200 sources. It told the FT: “Where facts are taken from multiple sources, no author would be expected to reference each and every one.”

;

;The FT pointed out that one of the themes of the book was the failure to properly acknowledge the work of female economists. It was launched on Wednesday night at a party in Carlton Gardens that included several members of the shadow cabinet, including Wes Streeting and Hilary Benn.

;
;

;;Related: ;;The Women Who Made Modern Economics by Rachel Reeves review – a personal manifesto;

;
;

;A 2021 foreword to a report on global development by Benn, for Tony Blair's Global Change thinktank, is one of the excerpts that appears to have been reworked in the book without acknowledgment. ;Benn wrote;: “When we were elected in 1997, the amount of aid we gave as a proportion of our national income had halved over the preceding 18 years and was just 0.26%. By the time we left office, we were on our way to achieving the 0.7% target. This was down to the political leadership of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, who brought the lives of the world's poorest people into the heart of Whitehall.”

;

;Reeves's book says: “When Labour was elected in 1997, the amount of aid the UK gave as a proportion of our national income had halved over the preceding 18 years and stood at just 0.26%. By the end of Labour's time in office, in 2010, we were on our way to achieving the 0.7% target. This was down to the political leadership of Blair and Gordon Brown – and their first secretary of state for international development from 1997 to 2002, Clare Short, who brought the lives of the world's poorest people into the heart of government.”

;

;The FT also found a passage in Reeves's book about the philosopher Elizabeth Anscombe that is very similar to an obituary published in the Guardian in 2001.

;

;;The obituary,; by Jane O'Grady, says: “Once, entering a smart restaurant in Boston, she was told that ladies were not admitted in trousers. She simply took them off.”

;

;Reeves writes: “Once, when entering a smart restaurant in Boston, she was told that ladies were not admitted in trousers, so she took them off there and then!”

;

;The FT reported that it found the similarities without using plagiarism detection software. It cited a number of examples from Wikipedia. These include an account of a clash between the writer HG Wells and Beatrice Webb, the social reformer and key figure in the Fabian Society.

;

;Reeves writes: “For her part, Beatrice voiced disapproval of Wells's 'sordid intrigue' with the daughter of a veteran Fabian member. He responded by lampooning the couple in his 1911 novel The New Machiavelli as Altiora and Oscar Bailey, a pair of short-sighted, bourgeois manipulators.”

;

;The ;Wikipedia entry on Webb; says: “For her part, Beatrice voiced disapproval of Wells' 'sordid intrigue' with the daughter of a veteran Fabian Sydney Olivier. He responded by lampooning the couple in his 1911 novel The New Machiavelli as Altiora and Oscar Bailey, a pair of short-sighted, bourgeois manipulators.”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 15:22:01 +0800 Cold war satellite images reveal hundreds of unknown Roman fortshttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/26/cold-war-satellite-images-hundreds-unknown-roman-forts
;;2023-10-26T04:00:25Z;
;
;;Declassified imagery from cold-war spy satellite programmes has revealed 396 Roman forts spread widely across the Syrian steppe.
;

;Declassified cold-war spy satellite images have thrown new light on the workings of the Roman empire by revealing hundreds of previously undiscovered forts, with dramatic implications for our understanding, experts have said.

;

;Archeologists examining aerial photographs taken in the 1960s and 70s said they reveal 396 sites of unknown Roman forts in Syria and Iraq across the Syrian steppe.

;

;The findings, ;published today in Antiquity;, an international archeology academic journal, have now forced a re-evaluation of life at the Roman frontier.

;

;A previous survey of the region in 1934 by Antoine Poidebard, a French Jesuit explorer who pioneered aerial archeology in the Middle East from his bi-plane, recorded a line of 116 forts.

;

;Until now, historians assumed these forts were part of a defensive line built to protect the eastern province of the empire from Arab and Persian incursions, and from nomadic marauding tribes intent on captive-taking and slave-raiding.

;

;The new discoveries instead point to the frontier being more fluid and a vibrant place of cross-border trade, rather than of constant violent conflict, the authors said, with the forts supporting a system of caravan-based interregional trade, communication and military transport.

;

;The authors said it now raises the question: “Was it a wall or a road?”

;

;“Since the 1930s, historians and archeologists have debated the strategic or political purpose of this system of fortifications,” said the lead author of ;the research, ;Prof Jesse Casana, of Dartmouth college in New Hampshire, US. “But few scholars have questioned Poidebard's basic observation that there was a line of forts defining the eastern Roman frontier.”

;

;The 396 new sites, hidden by modern-day development, are widely distributed across the region from east to west, which does not support the argument that the forts constituted a north-south border wall.

;

;Researchers now hypothesise that the forts were constructed to support cross-border trade, protecting caravans travelling between the eastern provinces and the non-Roman territories, as well as facilitating communications between east and west.

;

;Significantly, this indicates that the borders of the Roman world were less rigidly defined and exclusionist than previously believed, said the authors.

;

;The Romans were a military society, but they clearly valued trade and communication with regions not under their direct control, they added.

;

;The images studied formed part of the world's first spy-satellite programme conducted at the time of geopolitical tension between the US and Soviet Union and their allies, the western bloc and the eastern bloc.

;

;They “preserve a high-resolution, stereo perspective on a landscape that has been severely impacted by modern-day land-use change,” said Casana.

;

;He said it revealed the real value of satellite imagery for recording archeological features before they are lost.

;

;“We were only able confidently to identify extant archeological remains of 38 of Poidebard's 116 forts. In addition, many of the likely Roman forts we have documented in this study have already been destroyed by recent urban or agricultural development, and countless others are under extreme threat.”

;

;As more imagery is declassified, such as U2 spy plane photographs, more new archeological discoveries will be able to be made. Casana said “careful analysis of these powerful data holds enormous potential for future discoveries in the near east and beyond”.

;;The moment a humpback whale landed on top of Jason Breen while he was windfoiling off Mona Vale beach in Sydney, New South Wales
;

;Jason Breen didn't think his GoPro was turned on to capture what happened while he was windfoiling at a ;Sydney; beach on Wednesday. Luckily it was, otherwise he thinks nobody would have believed him.

;

;The 55-year-old Newport resident was cruising along the water at Mona Vale beach when a humpback whale soared out of the water and landed on top of him, dragging him about 20 to 30 feet below the surface.

;

;“I thought I was gone to be honest,” Breen said. “I thought for a few seconds, 'This is what it's like to die'.”

;

;As he wrestled beneath the whale, he could feel its smooth skin against his own, leading him to believe it was a juvenile.

;

;

;On a headland above, a bystander saw it unfold, and had punched triple 0 into his phone, waiting to see if Breen resurfaced.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Man dies after suspected whale collision capsizes boat in Sydney ;

;
;

;Then his leg rope snapped, and he clawed his way back to the surface and to his board. When he made it to the shore, he saw some mates and told them what happened.

;

;“They just went 'Yeah, sure!'” Breen said. “They thought I was telling a made up story, then I realised my GoPro had captured it all.”

;

;The bystander on the headland had also happened to be filming Breen windfoiling across the beach just as the whale breached and landed on top of him. Windfoiling is similar to wind surfing.

;

;Last month, ;a 61-year-old man died after a whale struck his boat; in Botany Bay and flung him and another man into the bay. Police believe the whale “may have breached near the boat, or on to the boat”.

;

;Breen said he was lucky it was a juvenile whale. If it was an adult, he doesn't think he'd be alive to tell the tale.

;“There's no way I'd be here, like I'd be gone for sure.” he said. “It was really a one in a million.”
